title: Oyster Sauce Substitute Options

items.name: Hoisin sauce
items.details: Sweeter and spiced, but same texture and richness. Add a splash of soy sauce to tone down sweetness. Good 1:1 substitute.

items.name: Soy sauce + honey/sugar
items.details: Mix 2 parts soy sauce with 1 part honey (or brown sugar) to mimic the salty-sweet balance. Good 1:1 substitute.

items.name: Fish sauce + soy sauce
items.details: Fish sauce has briny umami punch; add soy for body. Use sparingly since fish sauce is stronger. Good 1:1 substitute.

items.name: Teriyaki sauce
items.details: Sweeter but still works in many dishes. A lighter option.

items.name: Miso paste + water/soy sauce
items.details: Earthy, umami-rich substitute. Great brushed on salmon. A lighter option.

notes: Oyster sauce is thick, savory, and slightly sweet with a deep umami flavor. For salmon specifically, the conversation also discussed topping sauces: soy sauce + honey + sesame oil (savory-sweet), hoisin + soy sauce (richer), soy sauce + rice vinegar + lime juice (bright and fresh), miso + honey + rice vinegar (tangy-sweet), spicy mayo with sriracha and lime (creamy/spicy), or teriyaki (classic caramelized). A shredded cabbage and carrot mix pairs well with salmon and rice - either as a quick stir-fry with garlic, ginger, and soy sauce, or as a raw slaw with rice vinegar, sesame oil, honey, and soy sauce.
